meanings.definition: The practice of scheduling more work or deliveries towards the end of a period.
meanings.sent1: In our project, we used backloading to ensure we could handle the increased workload at the end.
meanings.sent2: The company's backloading strategy helped them manage the busy season effectively.
meanings.sent3: The team joked that backloading all the tasks was like saving the best for last.
meanings.sent4: Backloading the assignments made the final days feel like a rush to complete everything.
meanings.sent5: The concept of backloading made the project timeline more flexible and adaptable.

meanings.definition: The act of loading goods onto a vehicle in a way that prioritizes items towards the rear.
meanings.sent1: The backloading of the truck ensured that heavier items were placed towards the back for stability.
meanings.sent2: The workers practiced backloading to make sure the fragile items were protected during transport.
meanings.sent3: Seeing the crew backloading the boxes reminded me of a puzzle being solved.
meanings.sent4: Backloading the supplies felt like building a tower from the ground up.
meanings.sent5: The efficiency of backloading the goods saved time and effort during loading and unloading.

meanings.definition: A method of payment where the majority of funds are received at the end of a project.
meanings.sent1: The contractor preferred backloading as it ensured a substantial payment upon completion.
meanings.sent2: Backloading the payment motivated the team to finish the project on time.
meanings.sent3: Receiving the payment through backloading felt like a reward for all the hard work.
meanings.sent4: The idea of backloading the funds added an element of anticipation to the project.
meanings.sent5: The client's choice of backloading the payment structure was beneficial for cash flow management.
